articles.headline: At the Hajj, Facing Islam’s Inconsistent Embrace of Women
articles.snippet: Our reporter, on her first hajj, says she “was at once frustrated by Islam’s nitpicky strictures on women’s dress and embraced by its warm sisterhood.”
articles.abstract: Our reporter, on her first hajj, says she “was at once frustrated by Islam’s nitpicky strictures on women’s dress and embraced by its warm sisterhood.”
articles.lead_paragraph: MECCA, Saudi Arabia — “Sister, where are your socks?” one of the women I was sitting with demanded. “Don’t you know you have to cover your feet?”

articles.headline: One Beneficiary of Clinton’s Complex Tax Plan: Tax Lawyers
articles.snippet: Hillary Clinton’s proposal would increase taxes on the rich and big business, while adding many new layers of complexity.
articles.abstract: Hillary Clinton’s proposal would increase taxes on the rich and big business, while adding many new layers of complexity.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s hard to imagine a tax code more complicated than the one we already have.

articles.headline: At BlackRock, a Wall Street Rock Star’s $5 Trillion Comeback
articles.snippet: Laurence Fink blew $100 million in 1986. Since then, as chief of BlackRock, he has built his firm into the world’s largest asset manager and changed the balance of power on Wall Street.
articles.abstract: Laurence Fink blew $100 million in 1986. Since then, as chief of BlackRock, he has built his firm into the world’s largest asset manager and changed the balance of power on Wall Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Laurence D. Fink, the leader and founder of BlackRock, the world’s largest asset manager, had come home.

articles.headline: People Are Watching Less TV. So Will They Watch the Emmys?
articles.snippet: This awards show is airing on Sunday on ABC, which hopes to buck a trend of falling ratings, even for big live events.
articles.abstract: This awards show is airing on Sunday on ABC, which hopes to buck a trend of falling ratings, even for big live events.
articles.lead_paragraph: [ Our full report on the 2016 Emmy Awards | the list of Emmy winners | red carpet looks | our critic’s review of the show ]

articles.headline: Department Stores Find Room to Grow in Canada
articles.snippet: Department stores are closing outlets in the United States, but Canada is looking like a lucrative frontier for some, including Nordstrom.
articles.abstract: Department stores are closing outlets in the United States, but Canada is looking like a lucrative frontier for some, including Nordstrom.
articles.lead_paragraph: TORONTO — The face-off begins Friday. At the north end of the Toronto Eaton Centre, a sprawling downtown mall, Nordstrom will open its first store in Canada’s largest city. At its south end, an iconic redbrick building houses the newly renovated flagship store of Canada’s department store giant, the Hudson’s Bay Company, and the first Canadian outlet of its subsidiary, Saks Fifth Avenue.
articles.byline: By Ian Austen and Rachel Abrams

articles.headline: Concern Over Colin Powell’s Hacked Emails Becomes a Fear of Being Next
articles.snippet: A panicked network anchor went home and deleted his entire personal Gmail account, and a Democratic senator began rethinking the virtues of a flip phone.
articles.abstract: A panicked network anchor went home and deleted his entire personal Gmail account, and a Democratic senator began rethinking the virtues of a flip phone.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A panicked network anchor went home and deleted his entire personal Gmail account. A Democratic senator began rethinking the virtues of a flip phone. And a former national security official gave silent thanks that he is now living on the West Coast.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Takes Aim at Voters Drifting Toward Third Party
articles.snippet: Mrs. Clinton’s Democratic allies plan a push to win over young people disaffected by both major party candidates who are now favoring Gary Johnson or Jill Stein.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Clinton’s Democratic allies plan a push to win over young people disaffected by both major party candidates who are now favoring Gary Johnson or Jill Stein.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hillary Clinton and her Democratic allies, unnerved by the tightening presidential race, are making a major push to dissuade disaffected voters from backing third-party candidates, and pouring more energy into Rust Belt states, where Donald J. Trump is gaining ground.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Amy Chozick

articles.headline: EpiPen Maker Lobbies to Shift High Costs to Others
articles.snippet: Inclusion on a federal list would mean Mylan could keep its list price high — or even raise it — without patients’ complaining. But consumers would feel it indirectly.
articles.abstract: Inclusion on a federal list would mean Mylan could keep its list price high — or even raise it — without patients’ complaining. But consumers would feel it indirectly.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Against a growing outcry over the surging price of EpiPens, a chorus of prominent voices has emerged with a smart-sounding solution: Add the EpiPen, the lifesaving allergy treatment, to a federal list of preventive medical services, a move that would eliminate the out-of-pocket costs of the product for millions of families — and mute the protests.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Rachel Abrams

articles.headline: Buying a Mattress Online Was Easy. Now, About the Return.
articles.snippet: Web-based mattress retailers vow they’ll take the product back if it flunks a comfy-sleep test. And they do, but it’s not simple.
articles.abstract: Web-based mattress retailers vow they’ll take the product back if it flunks a comfy-sleep test. And they do, but it’s not simple.
articles.lead_paragraph: Here is your mattress shopping bill of rights, 2016 edition:

articles.headline: Going for the Gold in the Golden Years
articles.snippet: Many fitness-oriented older Americans, some who came to sports later in life, test themselves in local, state and national competitions like the Senior Games.
articles.abstract: Many fitness-oriented older Americans, some who came to sports later in life, test themselves in local, state and national competitions like the Senior Games.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three times a week David Gladfelter, an 80-year-old semiretired lawyer, dons a swimsuit, goggles and cap. For the next hour, varying his strokes, he swims 80 laps at a community center pool.
